title: Automated Knitting Machine
text:
The idea behind this project draws inspiration from the operating principle of 3D printers: starting from a digital model, they can automatically produce three-dimensional objects with precision and repeatability.
The objective of this project is to transpose this paradigm to the textile field by developing an automated knitting machine capable of producing knit patterns from a predefined digital design.

title: Error Recognition
text:
The first step toward automating such an ancient and traditional technique is the ability to detect production errors in real time.
An integrated vision system must be able to identify the occurrence of anomalies (for example, missing yarn or skipped stitches),
allowing the machine to intervene and stop the process before the defect fully develops, preventing serious errors and material waste.

title: Error Recognition
text:
Missing thread: no yarn present during a stitch.
Thread break: yarn snapped or slack beyond tolerance.
Mis-stitch / skipped stitch: hook failed to catch/transfer the loop.
Jams / obstruction: mechanical interference preventing motion.
Backlash / positioning drift: kinematic error causing misplaced stitches.
Lighting drift: exposure or color shift degrading vision accuracy.

title: Error Recognition
text:
Sensing: camera frames + optional encoders / tension sensor.
Preprocessing: crop, denoise, exposure normalization.
Inference: lightweight CNN / classical vision (edges, morphology).
Decision logic: thresholds, temporal filtering, hysteresis.
Action: warn, pause, retry, or safe-stop with guided recovery.

title: Error Recognition
text:
Classes: {ok, missing_thread, break, mis_stitch, jam}.
Labeling protocol: annotate bounding boxes/masks around hook & loop region; store frame index + machine state.
Split: train/val/test with subject and lighting stratification.
Augmentations: brightness/contrast jitter, small blur, slight rotations.

title: Error Recognition
text:
Per-class F1 and macro-F1 as primary.
Latency (ms/frame), throughput (fps), false alarm rate (%/hr).
MTTD (mean time to detection) for critical faults.

title: Error Recognition
text:
Target: ‚â• 25‚Äì30 fps @ 320‚Äì640 px ROI.

Fail-safe: if confidence < threshold for N frames ‚Üí degrade to safe mode.

title: Error Recognition
text:
Requirements

Shutter: global preferred (avoid motion artifacts on fast hooks).
Frame rate: ‚â• 60 fps recommended; ‚â• 120 fps if fast cycles.
Resolution: enough to resolve the loop region (typically 320‚Äì800 px ROI on the hook).
Interface: CSI (low latency) or USB3 (ubiquitous). GigE only if long cable runs.
Lens: C/CS-mount or M12 with suitable focal length; low distortion.
Lighting: diffuse LED ring or backlight; fixed CCT; flicker-free.
Sync: exposure synced to machine phase (encoder or GPIO trigger) if possible.
Mounting: rigid, vibration-damped, easy to re-calibrate.

title: Error Recognition
text:
Candidate Options (Examples)

Raspberry Pi Camera (HQ / v3): CSI, low latency, good ecosystem; pick global shutter variant for fast motion.
USB3 industrial (e.g., IMX sensors): robust drivers, global shutter options, flexible lenses; slightly higher cost.
Low-cost USB webcams: easy, but rolling shutter + auto-exposure can hurt reliability.

title: Error Recognition
text:
Recommended Baseline

Global-shutter camera (CSI or USB3) + fixed-focus lens covering the hook area + diffuse LED lighting.
Lock exposure/white balance; disable auto features.
Optional GPIO trigger to align exposure with hook phase.

title: Error Recognition
text:
Recovery & HMI

On detection: pause motion at safe phase, highlight ROI capture, show probable cause and guided steps (e.g., re-thread).
Operator tools: snapshot, slow-motion replay (last 0.5‚Äì1.0 s), one-click retry.

title: Error Recognition
text:
Roadmap

Phase 1: classical vision baseline (edges + region stats).
Phase 2: lightweight CNN for robustness to yarn/lighting variants.
Phase 3: multi-sensor fusion (tension + vision) and predictive alarms.

title: Selection of the Acquisition System for Error Detection on a Raspberry Pi 3 model B+
text:
The goal of the system is to ensure automatic monitoring of the knitting process at each hook movement.
A micro switch provides a synchronization signal, allowing the vision system to verify that the yarn ‚Äî regardless of its color, thickness, or texture ‚Äî is correctly positioned around the base of the hook.
In particular, the yarn should take on a ‚ÄúU‚Äù-shaped configuration embracing the base of the hook.
Any configuration that does not match this pattern must be detected as an error.
When an anomaly is detected, the system should: - Immediately stop the motor driving the process;
- Display an error message and indicate the index of the corresponding hook.

title: Selection of the Acquisition System for Error Detection on a Raspberry Pi 3 model B+
text:
Requirements
To meet these objectives, the choice of camera and acquisition system must satisfy the following requirements:

Compatibility with Raspberry Pi 3: use of natively supported interfaces and libraries.

Ease of software integration: availability of well-established computer vision libraries (e.g., libcamera, Picamera2, OpenCV).

Cost-effectiveness: a sensor with sufficient resolution to distinguish fine yarn details, while keeping costs low.

Close-focus capability: ability to capture sharp images at short distances, near the hook area.

Compact dimensions: a small camera module to facilitate mechanical integration within the machine‚Äôs 3D frame.

Low power consumption: efficient power usage to minimize the overall system load.
